UK

BoE's Haldane said it is important to push inflation back to 2% target and not wait too long, while he reportedly sees 'shaken confidence' in central banks. (Handelsblatt)

UK PM May said they have an agreement or are close to doing so on everything except Northern Ireland. PM May also commented that they want a future customs relationship with the EU in place by 2020 to make sure a backstop is not necessary and that EEA membership for the UK would not deliver on the vote for Brexit. (Newswires)

EU sources said the proposals in a draft of UK PM May's white paper on Brexit will never be accepted by the EU. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 54.4 vs. Exp. 54.0 (Prev. 54.4, Rev. 54.3). (Newswires)


EU

German Interior Minister Seehofer said he will stay on in the role and that he has a clear agreement with Chancellor Merkel. (Newswires)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Jun) 54.9 vs. Exp. 55.0 (Prev. 55.0). (Newswires)
EU Unemployment Rate (May) 8.4% vs. Exp. 8.5% (Prev. 8.5%)


COMMODITIES

US State Department Senior Policy Adviser Hook said the US is working with oil market participants to ensure stability in the oil market. (Newswires)
 

US

US President Trump said if the WTO does not treat the US properly we will be doing something, while he also commented that the administration will soon be meeting the EU about trade and that they are 'very close' to making some fair trade deals. Furthermore, US President Trump is said to have spoken with Mexico's election winner AMLO about border security, NAFTA, trade and possibly a separate trade deal with Mexico. (Newswires)

Mexican President-elect Obrador said he spoke on the phone with US President Trump for half an hour and that talks included a comprehensive deal on job-creating development projects to reduce migration and strengthen security. In related news, an economic adviser to the President-elect stated that Mexico should hit back if US imposes auto tariffs and suggested they would be happy for NAFTA renegotiation to conclude before December. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said it is too early to talk about leaving the WTO and commented that the stock market level will not change policy. (Newswires)

US ISM Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 60.2 vs. Exp. 58.4 (Prev. 58.7). (Newswires)
US Markit Manufacturing PMI Final (Jun) 55.4 vs. Exp. 54.6 (Prev. 54.6)
US Construction Spending MM (May) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 1.8%, Rev. 0.9%)
 

MARKET RECAP

US equity futures initially began lower, although the Emini S&P later found support ahead of the psychological level 2700 and pared back some of the earlier losses. Focus on Monday was on Dell technologies (DVMT) (class v stock of Dell) and VM Ware (VMW). Dell is to become a public traded company once again, by purchasing its own tracking stock of VM Ware, Dell Technologies, by offering 1.3665 shares of its Class C dell stock or an optional cash election. VM Ware will pay a USD 11bln dividend to DVMT holders as part of the deal announcement, dependent upon satisfaction of the deal. This reportedly removes the chance of a reverse merger for VM Ware (VMW), but sources over the weekend who knew about the matter, suggested Dell may pursue a merger with VM Ware down the line. Also, VM Ware would own between 20.8% to 31% of Dell after the deal, depending how many investors choose the cash option. Elsewhere, Casino names such as Wynn Resorts (WYNN) hampered the SPX on Monday following lower than expected casino revenue from Macau, which also hit Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Melco (MLCO). SPX +0.3%, NASDAQ COMP +0.7%, DJIA +0.2%.

Treasuries were lower on Monday, breaking their inverse relationship with equities, which also remained in negative territory for most of the the session. The yield curve bear-flattened with most of the selling action concentrated in the front end of the curve where 2yr and 5yr yields were higher by c.2bps, though action and volume was thin ahead of the US holiday this week. 2s10s and 2s30 narrowed by less than 2bps. US 10YR T-notes futures (Sep 2018) 3+ ticks lower at 120-02+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 2nd July 2018 - Protectionist fear lingers, equities rebound ahead of US holiday
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • * SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, DXY up, Crude down.
  • * REAR-VIEW: US Manufacturing PMI beat, German government crisis looms, Brexit new customs model, AMLO wins Mexican elections.
  • * AHEAD: Riksbank and RBA Rate Decisions, UK Construction PMI & US Factory Orders, Riksbank's Jochnick & Skingsley, ECB's Praet and BoE's Saunders to speak, US Markets to close early.

 

* TRADE: US President Trump said they will soon be meeting the EU about trade and added to be 'very close' in making some fair trade deals. He also said to have spoken about order security, NAFTA, trade and possibly a separate trade deal with Mexico in a phone call with Mexico's presidential elections winner Lopez Obrador. Separately, Trump announced if the WTO does not treat the US properly the nation will be doing something, although refrained from saying that the US would leave the organisation. Earlier in the day US Commerce Secretary Ross said it is too early to talk about leaving the WTO, adding that the stock market level will not change policy. Focus this week turns to the US $34 billion worth of tariffs to be imposed on Chinese imports, effective from July 6th , as well as the retaliatory response from China which is set to levy an extra 25% tariff on American auto imports.

* GEOPOLITICS: Some senior US President Trump officials are hoping the President may hold a round-table talk with Kim Jong Un in September in New York.

* GERMAN GOVERNMENT CRISIS: Bild reported the German CDU was apparently close to a deal with the CSU on the migrant crisis, at a meeting taking place Monday evening between Germany's CDU and CSU, aimed at solving disagreements over the issue. This comes in the context of Germany Interior Minister and CSU party leader Seehofer making a resignation offer following disagreements over the weekend with Chancellor Merkel on the deal that was negotiated at the EU summit.

Earlier on Monday, leader Seehofer dismissed his resignation offer and was said to remain in politics if Chancellor Merkel's CDU party was to back down regarding migration, while he also said he wants to avoid the collapse of Merkel's government.

Note the resignation of Interior Minister Seehofer would pose a serious threat to the CDU/CSU coalition; a break up of the alliance would weaken Germany’s Merkel position as she would remain Chancellor of a minority government.

* BREXIT: The BBC reported that Downing Street has produced a third model for handling customs after the UK leaves the EU.  Specific details of the new plan have not been revealed publicly though a senior UK minister noted "I think it'll be a hybrid, complex fudge specifically tailored for a different regime for goods and services". Senior ministers will discuss the new customs option at Chequers, the PM's country retreat, on Friday.

* MEXICO’S ELECTIONS: Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador won a decisive victory in the Presidential election, as expected,  with quick count results showing he received 53.0%-53.8% of votes. The new leader Lopez Obrador said he will have a frank dialogue with the US and seek a friendly relationship, adding he will continue NAFTA negotiations with the country.

* BOE SPEAK: BoE’s Haldane said it is important to push inflation back to 2% target and not wait too long. Note he dissented at the last BoE meeting.

* DATA: The US ISM Manufacturing PMI for June came in at 60.2, beating expectations at 58.4. The components slightly missed expectations, though they remained solid and provide support for Q2 economic growth above 4%. Prices Paid continue to signal increases in input prices for manufacturing firms, New Orders support further business investment and Employment remains robust; analysts at Wells Fargo say.

* SPX +0.3%, NASDAQ COMP  +0.7%, DJI  +0.2%. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals -0.2%, Cons Non-Cyclicals:        -0.7%, Energy: -1.5%, Financials: +0.3%, Health Care:   +0.1%, Industrials: 0.0%, Materials: -0.6%, Telecoms: 0.0%, Tech: +0.7%, Utilities: +0.5%.

* Futures: US Equity futures traded lower overnight where the Emini500 found support ahead of the psychological level 2700, before paring back some of the earlier losses.

* Stock Specifics: Focus on Monday was on Dell technologies (DVMT) (class v stock of Dell) and VM Ware (VMW). Dell is to become a public traded company once again, by purchasing its own tracking stock of VM Ware, Dell Technologies, by offering 1.3665 shares of its Class C dell stock or an optional cash election. VM Ware will pay a USD 11bln dividend to DVMT holders as part of the deal announcement, dependent upon satisfaction of the deal. This reportedly removes the chance of a reverse merger for VM Ware (VMW), but sources over the weekend who knew about the matter, suggested Dell may pursue a merger with VM Ware down the line. Also, VM Ware would own between 20.8% to 31% of Dell after the deal, depending how many investors choose the cash option.

Elsewhere, Casino names such as Wynn Resorts (WYNN) hampered the SPX on Monday following lower than expected casino revenue from Macau, which also hit Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Melco (MLCO). 

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (SEP 2018) 3+ TICKS LOWER AT 120-02+. Treasuries were lower on Monday, breaking their inverse relationship with equities, which also remained in negative territory for most of the the session. The yield curve bear-flattened with most of the selling action concentrated in the front end of the curve where 2yr and 5yr yields were higher by c.2bps, though action and volume was thin ahead of the US holiday this week. 2s10s and 2s30 narrowed by less than 2bps.

* WTI FUTURES (Q8) SETTLE  $0.21 LOWER AT $73.94/BBL; BRENT (Q8) FUTURES SETTLE $1.93 LOWER AT $77.30/BBL.

The recent rally of oil seems to have ran out of steam with losses limited in WTI, and Brent down more than 1%. Over the weekend US President Trump tweeted that he asked Saudi King Salman to increase output by as much as 2mln BPD, however the White House stated that the Saudis could increase the output if required, and that there was not an actual agreement to do so.  In the early morning we saw Russia’s output for June increase to 11.063mln BPD, 100kBPD increase (1.1%) and 0.8% increase m/m, however its exports did fall by 1.3% m/m. In other news the NOC confirmed source reports on Friday that a Force Majeure has been declared today on its Zueitina and Hariga oil ports.

 * USD: A solid start to July/Q3/H2 for the Greenback with broad gains made vs major and EM rivals amidst ongoing global trade/import tariff wars, plus political factors weighing on certain currencies, like the EUR, GBP and MXN. The index reclaimed 95.000+ status, as EURUSD retreated to just above 1.1600 having breached chart support (10 DMA circa 1.1623) ahead of a crisis meeting between Germany’s 3 grand coalition parties to try and iron out migration policy differences. Big option expiry interest between 1.1590-1.1600 (1.25 bn) stemmed the decline into the NY cut, while Cable also held within a cluster of expiries from 1.3095-1.3130 (1.1 bn) after failing to derive lasting support from a firmer than forecast UK manufacturing PMI. The Peso got an initial boost from news that AMLO secured a comfortable, if not resounding election victory to trade as high as 19.6455 vs the USD, but also succumbed to overall Dollar strength even though the new leader attempted to quell concerns about fiscal laxity. USDMXN currently back up over 20.0000.

* AUD, NZD: Extended losses vs their US counterpart and exchanged places at the foot of the G10 table over the course of Monday’s session as AUDUSD held just above ytd lows ahead of Tuesday’s RBA policy meeting, but NZDUSD edged closer to 0.6700 and the cross inched up to test 1.0950. The Kiwi may have been wary about another weak GDT auction result tomorrow after declines in prices of late.

* CAD, CHF: Also losing out to widespread USD strength (helped by upbeat manufacturing PMI and ISM headline prints), with the Loonie just above 1.3200 and Franc down under 0.9950.

* JPY: Relatively resilient vs the USD and rangebound having recovered from 111.00+ lows to meander from 110.50-90, with the JPY seeing some demand on safe-haven positioning.

* YUAN: The CNY and CNH fell further in wake of another firm PBoC midpoint fix and weaker than expected Chinese official and Caixin manuf PMIs, with the offshore unit testing multi-year lows vs the USD around 6.6900.

* COMING-UP:

* RBA Interest Rate Decision due at 0530BST/2330CDT. The RBA is expected to maintain the Cash Rate Target at the record low 1.50%. Expectations for the RBA to remain on hold for a prolonged period are largely due to subdued wage growth and inflation remaining below the central banks 2%-3% target band. The data points since the last meeting have been mixed with GDP growth for Q1 firmer than expected whilst jobs data has been less encouraging. For the full preview click here.

* Riksbank Interest Rate Decision Due Tuesday due at 0830BST/0230CDT. Analysts unanimously expect the Riksbank to keep rates unchanged at -0.50%. Housing market slowdown poses some downside risk for GDP. Core inflation has become the focus, with this painting a subdued picture. For the full preview click here.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 2nd July 2018 - Dell announced a buyout of shares which track the performance of its cloud software unit, VM Ware
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • VM Ware (VMW) / Dell Tech. (DVMT) – Dell announced a buyout of shares which track the performance of its cloud software unit, VM Ware, which will make Dell a publicly traded company again.
  • General Electric (GE) - JP Morgan says the remaining part of the co.’s business is significantly overvalued
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The electric vehicle maker reached its Model 3 milestone of 5000 per week

 

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) - The tech giant is reportedly unlikely to decide soon on buying modem chips from MediaTek in its next gen iPhones. (DigiTimes)
  • Boeing (BA) – The jet manufacturer has been awarded a USD 4.2bln navy contract modification for 1574 vehicles and 7538 kits, estimation of competition is the end of September 2019. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The bank has agreed to review how it sells its shares to investors in Australia, following an Australian regulator fined its local arm for not notifying the market about dwindling interest in a block trade back in 2015. (Newswires)
  • Merck (MRK) – The pharmaceutical giant’s and AstraZeneca’s (AZN LN) Lynparza has been approved in Japan for the treatment of mutated metastatic breast cancer. Separately, it announced the FDA gave priority review for supplemental Biologics License Application for Keytruda. (Newswires)
  • Pfizer (PFE) – The pharmaceutical giant is to hike drug prices on over 100 products. Separately, The New York Times stated emergency rooms are facing severe shortages of commonly used drugs, in part because of problems at Pfizer’s plants, and states shortages of morphine are especially severe. (Newswires / Axios)
  • Walmart (WMT) / Target (TGT) – Walmart is planning to use autonomous robots in more stores by next year to scan the inventory on shelves to detect products which are out of date and so it can direct workers to the issue. Target are also planning to add automatic cash counting machines to almost 2000 stores this summer. Also, of note for Walmart, Indian shopkeepers and traders with affiliations to a local lobby group started sit in protests across country in protest of the USD 16bln acquisition of Flipkart. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) – The co. announced the proposed acquisition of Neovia a provider of animal nutrition solutions, for EUR 1.5bln. (Newswires)
  • Auto names (TSLA, F, GM) – Carmakers are preparing for additional tariffs from China as they are set to impose an extra 25% tariff on American auto imports this week, according to WSJ. (WSJ)
  • Barron’s negative on Qualcomm (QCOM), says they may be the first to get hit following trade tensions with China, and Harley Davidson (HOG) saying shares are likely to become cheaper. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s positive on Electronic Arts (EA), Verizon (VZ), Mastercard (MA), Equity Common Wealth (EQC), Graco (GGG), says they are balance sheet winners. Also positive on Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), CVS Health (CVS), Rite Aid (RAD), Cardinal Health (CAH), McKesson (MCK) and AmerisourceBergen (ABC), saying shares have over reacted to Amazon’s acquisition of Pillack. (Newswires)
  • BB&T (BBT) – The co. has announced to terminate its consent order related to anti-money laundering controls. (Newswires)
  • Blackrock (BLK) – The co. has been removed from JP Morgan’s focus list. (Newswires)
  • Conoco Phillips (COP) – The shale producers CEO sees production in the US increasing over the next few years, despite the pipeline capacity disruption in Texas. (FT)
  • Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) – The co. is to be replaced by Copart (CPRT) in the S&P500 today. (Newswires)

Leaders of Germany's three coalition parties are planning to meet Monday evening to try and solve the government crisis; according to party sources
analysis_details:
• This follows from earlier reports that Germany Interior Minister and CSU party leader Seehofer is said to remain in politics if Chancellor Merkel's CDU party backs down regarding migration, while he also said he wants to avoid the collapse of Merkel's government and is said to be seeking one more discussion with the CDU. CSU caucus chief Dobrindt opposed the resignation and requested an internal vote, while there were also comments from Economy Minister Altmaier who stated that the German coalition is in a serious situation.
  • Previously Germany Interior Minister and CSU party leader Seehofer offered to resign, which follows a meeting over the weekend with Chancellor Merkel that Seehofer described as pointless and in which he rejected the migration deal that was negotiated at the EU summit.

subject: EU sources say the proposals in a draft of UK PM May's white paper on Brexit will never be accepted by the EU
content: Link to article here
analysis_details: • The white paper is expected to propose the UK remaining indefinitely in a single market for goods after Brexit, to avoid the need for checks at the Irish border. While the UK is offering concessions on financial services, it wants restrictions on free movement of people.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 2nd July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Risk tone soured in Europe as US tariffs concerns and German political instability lead all equity markets into negative territory
  • US President Trump said he spoke to Saudi Arabia’s King Salman on raising production by as much as 2mln barrels and that prices were too high, which the Saudi ruler agreed with
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US mfg PMIs, US construction spending, ISM manufacturing and ECB’s Praet

ASIA

Asian equity markets began H2 softer with the region constrained by disappointing data releases including Chinese Official & Caixin Manufacturing PMIs which both fell short of estimates, while the latest BoJ Tankan survey was mixed with headline Large Manufacturing Index also below forecasts. As such, ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-2.2%) were lacklustre although strength in Property and Healthcare sectors kept Australia afloat for most the session, while Japan was dampened following mixed Tankan data but with a weaker JPY intiially limiting the downside. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) was among the underperformers after both the Official and Caixin Manufacturing PMI missed estimates, while PBoC inaction resulting to a net daily drain and the absence of participants in Hong Kong for public holiday also ensured a subdued tone. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher amid the cautious risk tone in Japan and BoJ’s presence in the market, while the less than impressive BoJ tankan survey and source reports the BoJ are to revise lower its CPI forecasts at this month’s Outlook Report is also seen to likely to keep the BoJ maintaining its ultra-loose policy for a prolonged period.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 20bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6157 (Prev. 6.6166)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 51.5 vs. Exp. 51.7 (Prev. 51.9).

Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 55.0 vs. Exp. 54.8 (Prev. 54.9)

Chinese Composite PMI (Jun) 54.4 (Prev. 54.6)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI Final (Jun) 51.0 vs. Exp. 51.1 (Prev. 51.1)

Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Index (Q2) 21 vs. Exp. 22 (Prev. 24).

Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Outlook (Q2) 21 vs. Exp. 20 (Prev. 20)

Japanese Tankan Large Non-Manufacturing Index (Q2) 24 vs. Exp. 23 (Prev. 23)

Japanese Tankan Large Non-Manufacturing Outlook (Q2) 21 vs. Exp. 22 (Prev. 20)

Japanese Large All Industry Capex (Q2) 13.6% vs. Exp. 9.3% (Prev. 2.3%)

New Zealand Treasury said March quarter Real GDP grew 0.5% which was below forecast in the Budget Economic and Fiscal Update and that annual current account deficit widened to NZD 7.9bln or 2.8% of GDP from NZD 7.7bln or 2.7% of GDP. Furthermore, the Treasury also stated it is seeing signs of less momentum in the economy. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US/MEXICO

Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador won a decisive victory in the Presidential election with quick count results showing he received 53.0%-53.8% of votes, while an exit poll also showed that Lopez Obrador is set to get a majority at the lower house. (Newswires)

UK PM May has vowed to defy cabinet plotters, telling aides that she will not be bullied out of office by ministers or hardline Brexiteers opposed to her EU plans. May has opted to stand and fight if Conservative MPs force a vote to oust her, adding that she is content to “win by one vote”. (Sunday Times)

UK PM May representative in Brexit discussions Robbins is said to have told ministers there is no chance for a bespoke trade deal with EU. (Times)

Downing Street has produced a third model for handling customs after the UK leaves the EU, specifics of the new plan have not been revealed publicly but senior ministers will discuss it at Chequers, the prime minister's country retreat, on Friday. One Senior UK Minister, in regards to the third model, said "I think it'll be a hybrid, complex fudge specifically tailored for a different regime for goods and services"; according to Sky News Senior Political Correspondent Rigby (BBC/Twitter)

Sky News Journal tweets "it looks like the White Paper has been pencilled in for July 12th, the very day that Donald Trump arrives in the UK". (Twitter)

UK Business Secretary Clark hinted the Brexit transition could be extended beyond 2020 to allow companies more time to prepare for Britain’s future relationship with the EU. (The Guardian)

Jacob Rees-Mogg has threatened UK PM May with a rebellion by Brexiteer Tory MPs if she doesn’t deliver a hard Brexit. (Sky News)

BoE's Cunliffe has warned that escalating trade wars, strains in emerging markets and a rising possibility of a Chinese credit crisis could combine into a “painful” experience for the British economy. (Sunday Times)

Italian Deputy-PM Salvini states that 2019’s European elections are an opportunity to create an “international alliance of populists” and overcome a “Europe of the elites”. (FT)

Germany Interior Minister and CSU party leader Seehofer offered to resign, which follows a meeting over the weekend with Chancellor Merkel that Seehofer described as pointless and in which he rejected the migration deal that was negotiated at the EU summit. However, reports later stated that Seehofer is said to remain in politics if Chancellor Merkel's CDU party backs down regarding migration, while he also said he wants to avoid the collapse of Merkel's government and is said to be seeking one more discussion with the CDU. (Newswires) CSU caucus chief Dobrindt opposed the resignation and requested an internal vote, while there were also comments from Economy Minister Altmaier who stated that the German coalition is in a serious situation. (Newswires)

EU warned that US car import tariffs could result to a global retaliation that could impact as much as USD 300bln of US goods. (FT)

US Commerce Department was reported on Friday to have begun a review of US export controls ordered by President Trump, which will align with CFIUS legislation requirement to review emerging and foundational technologies essential to US national security. In separate news, there were also reports on Friday that US President Trump is said to have told advisors he wants the US to withdraw from the WTO. (Newswires)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Jun) 54.9 vs. Exp. 55.0 (Prev. 55.0)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 54.4 vs. Exp. 54.0 (Prev. 54.4, Rev. 54.3)

EU Unemployment Rate (May) 8.4% vs. Exp. 8.5% (Prev. 8.5%)

EQUITIES

European equities kick off the week in negative territory, albeit off lows (Eurostoxx 50 -1.0%) following the tone seen in the Asia-Pac session, with sentiment also dampened by the latest developments in Germany. Over the weekend, German Interior Minister Seehofer rejected Chancellor Merkel’s deal with the EU on migration whilst also threatening to resign. Trade war woes continue to linger after the EU threatened to impose new retaliatory tariffs worth USD 300bln if the US continues with the EU auto tariffs.

Financials and industrials underperform amid the uncertainty surrounding the potential fall of the German government (Interior Minister Seehofer is to meet Chancellor Merkel today) and the fall of base metals. Energy names take a hit following the recent decline in oil prices. In terms of stocks specifics, Microfocus (+5.1%) shares were lifted following reports they’re to sell their SUSE business to EQT partners for USD 2.4bln. Vedanta (+26.8%) shares spiked higher after Volcan approached the company with a buyout offer. Meanwhile, Playtech (-29.3%) shares slumped after the company lowered their guidance.

FX

EUR - The single currency has been under pressure in early EU trade, as 1.1700 held firm vs the Usd amidst reports of decent selling against vs the JPY after the cross breached 129.00 to the downside, from 128.95 to 125.80. Meanwhile, a prominent US bank has also implemented a short Eur position on unstable German political grounds and despite the prospect of SNB intervention via the CHF around 1.1550, targeting 1.1200 with a 1.1660 stop. Back to the headline pair, 1.1623 represents 10 DMA support just below the base so far.

USD - Although the Dollar has retreated from best levels vs several major counterparts the DXY remains underpinned above 94.500 with Usd/Jpy holding midway between 110.50-111.05 and the Greenback broadly firmer across the board. Sub-forecast Chinese PMIs suggest that trade wars may hit the world’s 2nd largest economy more than the US, and the YUAN continues to weaken in response if not by design.

AUD/NZD - Among the G10 underperformers on the latest downturn in overall risk sentiment, and with the Aud also undermined by a slower PMI print and decline in job ads overnight, as it slips further below 0.7400 vs its US peer and pivots 1.0900 against the Kiwi that is striving to keep its head above 0.6750 vs the Usd.

GBP - Fleeting respite and some welcome relief from the latest negative Brexit reports for the Pound as the UK manufacturing PMI beat expectations to remain relatively steady and comfortably above the 50.0 threshold. Cable has ticked up from sub-1.3150 levels, while Eur/Gbp has drifted down below 0.8850, albeit with the aid of aforementioned single currency weakness.

CAD/CHF - The Loonie and Franc are both relatively rangebound, but softer vs the Dollar on tariff factors, a softer Swiss manufacturing PMI and fall in retail sales. Usd/Cad is hovering in a 1.3140-90 range and Usd/Chf between 0.9900-30.

MXN - Off recent peaks vs the Usd, but with the Peso still holding above 20.000 in wake of the election and convincing win for AMLO

COMMODITIES

Commodities trade lower with WTI (-0.4%) and Brent (-0.9%) pressured as markets react to a tweet from US President Trump over the weekend that he spoke with Saudi Arabia’s King Salman on raising production maybe by as much as 2mln barrels and that prices were too high which the Saudi ruler agreed with. However, the White House were quick on clarifying that Saudi Arabia stated they could raise output if required and that there was no actual agreement to raising output by the said amount. In regards to this, Iran’s OPEC Governor Ardebili said on Saturday “there is no way one country could go 2mln BPD above their production allocation unless they are walking out of OPEC”. An Iranian official later stated that adjustments to the OPEC output levels would require an emergency meeting.

Amongst the weekend comments, Saudi crude output reached a near-record 10.7mln BPD according to a survey while Russian June output reached over 11mln BPD according to the oil ministry. Libya’s NOC declared a force majeure at Hariga and Zeutina ports while weekend reports suggested around 850K BPD may be offline in the country.

Elsewhere, gold (-0.3%) is subdued by a slightly firmer dollar as the yellow metal continues to be detached from the risk sentiments. Chinese iron ore futures fell almost 2% on Monday, due to a  fresh increase in iron ore stocks at China’s ports, after a hat trick of positive closes last week.

Note, Canadian tariffs came into play on Sunday, where a 25% levy imposed largely targeting US steel and aluminium products as well as a 10% tariff on over 250 other US goods (such as beer kegs, whisky, and orange juice).

FIXED INCOME

Having extended upside ranges to 162.89 and 123.35 (+34 and +29 ticks respectively), Bunds and Gilts have both pulled back quite markedly, while EU stocks pare losses amidst the raft of manufacturing PMIs. In truth the rally in core bonds never really resembled a full-blown FTQ, and the German benchmark was somewhat caught between supportive external impulses vs the potential negatives of the political divisions in Berlin. Hence, a recoil and a degree of underperformance to a 162.42 low vs its UK equivalent that held parity at 123.06 even though the UK release came in above consensus. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are even more resilient after last week’s heavy supply and the curve is flatter yet again ahead of Markit PMI, ISM and construction spending.

subject: Iranian official states that adjustments to OPEC output levels would require an emergency meeting
analysis_details: • Recap: Over the weekend, US President Trump tweeted that he asked Saudi Arabia’s King Salman to raise production maybe up to 2mln bpd to make up for Iran and Venezuela, while Trump added that prices are too high and that King Salman has agreed. The White House later clarified that Saudi Arabia has 2mln bbls of spare capacity and could raise output if needed but didn’t vow to raise it by a stated amount.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures: tracking firm core counterparts pre-manufacturing PMI
content: Gilts and Short Sterling contracts on the front foot and following their peers higher in early Liffe trade amidst another bout of risk aversion in equity markets on recurring/ongoing themes like heightened global protectionism, political in-fighting both on the domestic front and abroad with adverse implications for Brexit negotiations. The 10 year UK benchmark kicked off 16 ticks above last Friday’s settlement level and advanced further to post a 123.29 high (+23 ticks on the day) before fading to a 123.14 base, while the 3 month strip is 1-2 ticks above parity ahead of the manufacturing PMI that is expected to moderate in headline terms.

subject: ECB says banks borrowed EUR 59mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 674.2bln with it overnight; excess liquidity EUR 1.78tln

European equity movers this morning: Microfocus (MCRO LN) +4.9%, ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) -1.5%, Airbus (AIR FP) -3.9%, Rio Tinto (RIO LN) -1.4%, Steinhoff (SNH GY) +3.6%, Meggitt (MGGT LN) -2.1%, Vedanta (VED LN) +27.2%
Bunds: grinding bid and range extension
content: A tentative, but firm start to the new week, month and quarter, as the 10 year German debt future opened just 2 ticks above the previous close at 162.57 before gathering more momentum to break out of its recent range and register a 162.84 peak, while the corresponding yield dips below 0.30% and core bonds in general benefit from a broad downturn in risk sentiment on persistent global trade jitters and renewed strains closer to home following latest CSU-CDU friction on migration policy. Back to Eurex, some consolidation off the highs ahead of the EU cash equity opens, but also in advance of the 163.00 handle and resistance just above the big figure. Ahead, Eurozone manufacturing PMIs on Monday’s agenda and unemployment data, with speeches from ECB’s Praet and Liikenen at his farewell event in Finland.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

29th June 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began H2 indecisive with the region constrained by disappointing data releases including Chinese Official & Caixin Manufacturing PMIs which both fell short of estimates, while the latest BoJ Tankan survey was mixed with headline Large Manufacturing Index also below forecasts. As such, ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) were lacklustre although strength in Property and Healthcare sectors kept Australia afloat for most the session, while Japan was dampened following mixed Tankan data but with a weaker JPY intiially limiting the downside. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.1%) was among the underperformers after both the Official and Caixin Manufacturing PMI missed estimates, while PBoC inaction resulting to a net daily drain and the absence of participants in Hong Kong for public holiday also ensured a subdued tone. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher amid the cautious risk tone in Japan and BoJ’s presence in the market, while the less than impressive BoJ tankan survey and source reports the BoJ are to revise lower its CPI forecasts at this month’s Outlook Report is also seen to likely to keep the BoJ maintaining its ultra-loose policy for a prolonged period.

FTSE

Hammerson (HMSO LN) – The co. has hired McKinsey & Co. ahead of a strategy presentation to shareholders next month. (Times)

Persimmon (PSN LN) – The co. has angered shareholders after splitting a GBP 300mln bonus between 130 staff. (Telegraph)

Talk Talk (TALK LN) – The co.’s founder Dunstone has used an 11% fall in the co.’s shares to buy GBP75k worth of shares. (Telegraph)

Barclays (BARC LN) – The co. has received some support in its battle vs. Bramson, the corporate raider, after S&P warned strategy changes could lower their credit rating. (Telegraph)

BP (BP/ LN) – The co. has had 4 super tankers that were chartered held up or delayed off China’s east coast over the last 2 months. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) – Labor costs at Australian iron ore minds have increased by up to 10%, according to sources. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Ryanair (RYA LN) – The German Pilot Union VC says talks with the co. have broken down. (Newswires)     

BROKER MOVES

DAX

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – The proposed JV with Tata Steel has been completed, with the expected 4,000 job losses to go ahead. UK Union workers have struck a positive tone, however, saying it will protect workers for many years to come. Elliot Advisers and Cevian Capital have criticised the terms of the deal, citing valuation concerns. (Sky News/Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Freenet (FNT GY) – The co. is to acquire just under 10% of Ceconomy (CEC GY). (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

INFINEON (IFX GY) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM EQUALWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – The co. is said to miss A320neo deliveries target on the back of Pratt engine problems. (Newswires)

Essilor (EI FP) – The co. and Delfin have extended the deadline of their combination agreement, with confidence they can pass antitrust processes in China and Turkey. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

EDF (EDF FP) – It was reported just before the close on Friday trade that EDF is said to sell its Dunkirk gas terminal for EUR 2.4bln. This has now been confirmed. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PSA GROUP (UG FP) REITERATED OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

SMI

Swisscom (SCMN SW) – The co.’s CEO says they are prepped for competition form Iliad in the Italian Phone market. (Newswires)

Nestle (NESN SW) – Activist Loeb has pressured the co. to split into 3 divisions, nutrition, groceries and beverages, so management can be held to account better. (FT)

Roche (ROG SW) – The co.’s IMPASSION130 study has shown that Tecentiq with Abraxane markedly reduces risk of disease worsening or death in people with metastatic negative breast cancer. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

The European Commission has warned that US President Trump’s tariff action on automobiles could spark a retaliation of up to USD 300bln. (Newswires)

Recordati (REC IM) – CVC Capital has acquired 51.8% of the name for EUR 3bln. (Newswires)

Unipol (UNI IM) – The co. has completed the acquisition of 15.06% of BPER Banca (BPE IM) shares. (Newswires)

Telefonica (TEF SM) – The co. is reportedly considering the sale of its fibre optics branch so as to raise the co.’s stock market value, as according to sources. (El Confidencial)

Tom Tom (TOM2 NA) – Co. are to continue providing data for Apple’s (AAPL) maps. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

US

* FUTURES: A quiet day on Friday for the Emini500 as it grinded higher amid no specific newsflow, however the gains were not enough for the index to finish in the green for the week. The ES found some support around the 50dma at 2722 before climbing higher at the open and settling around the 2740 level. In late trade a large market imbalance was seen which led to some selling in the ES erasing some of the earlier gains

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 2nd July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets began H2 indecisively with the region constrained by disappointing data releases including Chinese Official & Caixin Manufacturing PMIs
  • EUR/USD hampered after CSU party leader Seehofer offered to resign amid the migration dispute
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Eurozone, UK and US mfg PMIs, US construction spending, ISM manufacturing and ECB’s Praet

ASIA

Asian equity markets began H2 indecisive with the region constrained by disappointing data releases including Chinese Official & Caixin Manufacturing PMIs which both fell short of estimates, while the latest BoJ Tankan survey was mixed with headline Large Manufacturing Index also below forecasts. As such, ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) were lacklustre although strength in Property and Healthcare sectors kept Australia afloat for most the session, while Japan was dampened following mixed Tankan data but with a weaker JPY intiially limiting the downside. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.1%) was among the underperformers after both the Official and Caixin Manufacturing PMI missed estimates, while PBoC inaction resulting to a net daily drain and the absence of participants in Hong Kong for public holiday also ensured a subdued tone. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher amid the cautious risk tone in Japan and BoJ’s presence in the market, while the less than impressive BoJ tankan survey and source reports the BoJ are to revise lower its CPI forecasts at this month’s Outlook Report is also seen to likely to keep the BoJ maintaining its ultra-loose policy for a prolonged period.
 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 20bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6157 (Prev. 6.6166)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 51.5 vs. Exp. 51.7 (Prev. 51.9).

Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 55.0 vs. Exp. 54.8 (Prev. 54.9)

Chinese Composite PMI (Jun) 54.4 (Prev. 54.6)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI Final (Jun) 51.0 vs. Exp. 51.1 (Prev. 51.1)
 

Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Index (Q2) 21 vs. Exp. 22 (Prev. 24).
Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Outlook (Q2) 21 vs. Exp. 20 (Prev. 20)
Japanese Tankan Large Non-Manufacturing Index (Q2) 24 vs. Exp. 23 (Prev. 23)

Japanese Tankan Large Non-Manufacturing Outlook (Q2) 21 vs. Exp. 22 (Prev. 20)
Japanese Large All Industry Capex (Q2) 13.6% vs. Exp. 9.3% (Prev. 2.3%)
 

UK

BoE's Cunliffe has warned that escalating trade wars, strains in emerging markets and a rising possibility of a Chinese credit crisis could combine into a “painful” experience for the British economy. (Sunday Times)

UK PM May has vowed to defy cabinet plotters, telling aides that she will not be bullied out of office by ministers or hardline Brexiteers opposed to her EU plans. May has opted to stand and fight if Conservative MPs force a vote to oust her, adding that she is content to “win by one vote”. (Sunday Times)

UK PM May representative in Brexit discussions Robbins is said to have told ministers there is no chance for a bespoke trade deal with EU. (Times)

Downing Street has produced a third model for handling customs after the UK leaves the EU, the BBC understands. Specifics of the new plan have not been revealed publicly but senior ministers will discuss it at Chequers, the prime minister's country retreat, on Friday. (BBC)

UK Business Secretary Clark hinted the Brexit transition could be extended beyond 2020 to allow companies more time to prepare for Britain’s future relationship with the EU. (The Guardian)

Jacob Rees-Mogg has threatened UK PM May with a rebellion by Brexiteer Tory MPs if she doesn’t deliver a hard Brexit. (Sky News)

Italian Deputy-PM Salvini states that 2019’s European elections are an opportunity to create an “international alliance of populists” and overcome a “Europe of the elites”. (FT)
 

EU

Germany Interior Minister and CSU party leader Seehofer offered to resign, which follows a meeting over the weekend with Chancellor Merkel that Seehofer described as pointless and in which he rejected the migration deal that was negotiated at the EU summit. However, reports later stated that Seehofer is said to remain in politics if Chancellor Merkel's CDU party backs down regarding migration, while he also said he wants to avoid the collapse of Merkel's government and is said to be seeking one more discussion with the CDU. (Newswires) CSU caucus chief Dobrindt opposed the resignation and requested an internal vote, while there were also comments from Economy Minister Altmaier who stated that the German coalition is in a serious situation. (Newswires)


FX

FX markets were mostly quiet, although the DXY attempted to recover last Friday’s lost ground which has resulted to a mild pull-back in EUR/USD with the single currency slightly hampered by political discord in Germany which threatens Merkel’s government after Interior Minister and CSU party leader Seehofer offered to resign amid migration dispute. The firmer greenback also saw GBP/USD relinquish the 1.3200 handle and USD/JPY briefly test 111.00 to the upside. Elsewhere, antipodeans weakened amid Trump-triggered oil declines and a pessimistic tone in the New Zealand Treasury’s economic indicators, while MXN was initially underpinned following the elections in which Lopez Obrador won a decisive victory and is also set for a majority in parliament. However, gains were reversed as markets digested the ramifications of a left-wing government which would likely have a much fiscally looser stance than some of its opponents.

New Zealand Treasury said March quarter Real GDP grew 0.5% which was below forecast in the Budget Economic and Fiscal Update and that annual current account deficit widened to NZD 7.9bln or 2.8% of GDP from NZD 7.7bln or 2.7% of GDP. Furthermore, the Treasury also stated it is seeing signs of less momentum in the economy. (Newswires)

Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador won a decisive victory in the Presidential election with quick count results showing he received 53.0%-53.8% of votes, while an exit poll also showed that Lopez Obrador is set to get a majority at the lower house. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Oil prices were pressured from the open and briefly fell below USD 73.00/bbl in reaction to a tweet from US President Trump over the weekend that he spoke with Saudi Arabia’s King Salman on raising production maybe by as much as 2mln barrels and that prices were too high which the Saudi ruler agreed with. However, the White House were quick on clarifying that Saudi Arabia stated they could raise output if required and that there was no actual agreement to raising output by the said amount. Nonetheless, oil prices gapped lower at the open and head into the European open with losses of around 1.2%. Elsewhere, gold prices were uneventful with mild pressure seen as the greenback nursed losses, while copper languished amid weakness in stocks and disappointing data from China.

US President Trump tweeted that he asked Saudi Arabia’s King Salman to raise production maybe up to 2mln bpd to make up for Iran and Venezuela, while Trump added that prices are too high and that King Salman has agreed. The White House later clarified that Saudi Arabia has 2mln bbls of spare capacity and could raise output if needed but didn’t vow to raise it by a stated amount. (Newswires/Twitter)

Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh is said to urge fellow OPEC members to refrain from unilateral measures in a letter to UAE Energy Minister and OPEC President in which Zanganeh also warned that any production increases above limits is in breech of the agreement. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia reportedly boosted June crude exports to highest since 2013, according to KPLER. (Newswires)

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (29 Jun) 1047 (Prev. 1052). (Newswires)

US

Treasury trading was particularly quiet on Friday despite it being month-end, quarter-end, and half-end. Heading into the afternoon, volumes declined as it appeared most market players tried to get away early ahead of the Independence Day holiday next week. Despite equities trending higher, the risk-on sentiment failed to send bonds lower with IFR noting slightly month-end demand keeping bonds elevated. US 10YR T-Notes futures (Sep 2018) settled unchanged at 120-06.

US President Trump said will wait until mid-term elections to decide on NAFTA and that he has no plans on backing down regarding China. Elsewhere, US President Trump said on Friday he is working on phase 2 of the tax plan and that he is considering cutting corporation tax again from 21% to 20%. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department was reported on Friday to have begun a review of US export controls ordered by President Trump, which will align with CFIUS legislation requirement to review emerging and foundational technologies essential to US national security. In separate news, there were also reports on Friday that US President Trump is said to have told advisors he wants the US to withdraw from the WTO. (Newswires)

EU warned that US car import tariffs could result to a global retaliation that could impact as much as USD 300bln of US goods. (FT)
